title: Havana, a ghost town battered by shortages and US threats
subhead: 'Cuba, an island adrift' (1/3) In the small socialist country, US pressure for regime change has reached its peak since the kidnapping of Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro on January 3. Daily life has become a nightmare, and public discourse is more closely monitored than ever.

title: French finance minister urges Capgemini explain its contract with ICE

Two immigration agents placed on leave after Alex Pretti's shooting
subhead: Intensive care unit nurse Alex Pretti was shot multiple times in Minneapolis on Saturday after being forced to the ground by camouflaged officers in a scuffle captured on video.

title: France is still trading uranium with Russia, nearly four years after Ukraine invasion
subhead: With uranium still spared from European Commission sanctions against Russia, the anti-nuclear NGO Greenpeace has highlighted that France remains tied to the Russian group Rosatom.

title: 'For sure': Two impromptu words by Macron go viral
subhead: During his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, the French president delivered a common English phrase – in a strong accent – that achieved global fame.

title: Charles Kushner, Trump's man in Paris
subhead: The 71-year-old US ambassador, who took up his post in May 2025, is the father of Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law and envoy to the Middle East. Like his son, he is known for his unorthodox methods and does not hesitate to interfere in France's domestic affairs.

2026 FIFA World Cup: Calls for boycott emerge to bring Trump 'to his senses'
subhead: The US president's desire to claim Greenland has prompted political figures to raise the possibility of national football teams withdrawing.

title: Richard Ford: 'I tell my European friends how it feels not to understand my country'
subhead: The novelist expresses concern, in an op-ed for Le Monde, about the direction his country has taken under President Donald Trump. He laments that Americans do not appear to pay attention to the erosion of their constitutional rights, nor do they grasp how difficult it will be to turn back.

title: Why there are so many French presidential hopefuls
subhead: As a result of political fragmentation, the growing number of figures who have declared their candidacies or are thinking about doing so is making the 2027 presidential election highly uncertain, writes Le Monde's Solenn de Royer in her column.
